lines.text: No, please, not tonight. Maybe tomorrow.

Oh, my dear little librarian. You pile up enough tomorrows, and you'll find you are left with nothing but a lot of empty yesterdays. I don't know about you, but I'd like to make today worth remembering.
Oh, so would I.
[in song]
Do you think that I'd allow a common masher - ? Now, really, mama. I have my standards where men are concerned and I have no intention...

I know all about your standards and if you don't mind my sayin' so there's not a man alive who could hope to measure up to that blend of Paul Bunyan, Saint Pat, and Noah Webster you've concocted for yourself out of your Irish imagination, your Iowa stubbornness, and your li'berry full of books!
[in song]
So what the heck? You're welcome! Join us at the picnic! You can eat your fill of all the food you bring yourself.
You watch your phraseology!
Now, George!
Not one poop out of you, Madame!

[turning to Zaneeta]
I think he means "peep"!

[looks back]
*Yes!*
I always think there's a band, kid.
Papa, please! It's 'Capulets' like you who make blood in the marketplace! Ye Gods!
Mayor Shinn, your honor, your daughter and I have been going steady behind your back.
What?
We'd rather be doing it in front of your back.
Doing what?
Well...
Never mind!
[in song]
When a woman's got a husband, and you've got none, why should she take advice from you? Even if you can quote Balzac and Shakespeare and all them other high-falutin' Greeks.
[in song]

Oh yes, that woman made brazen overtures, with a guilt-edge guarantee / She had a golden glint in her eye and a silver voice with a counterfeit ring / Just melt her down and you'll reveal / a lump of lead as cold as steel / Here, where a woman's heart should be.
Don't believe I caught your name.
Don't believe I *dropped* it.
The librarian hasn't felt much like doing research lately, but she did plenty when you first came here.
What about?
Professor Harold Hill. Gary Conservatory of Music, gold medal class of '05. Harold, there wasn't any Gary Conservatory of Music in '05.
Why, there most certainly w...
Because the town wasn't even built until '06. I tore this page out of an Indiana Journal. I was going to use it against you, but now I give to you with all my heart.
Thar she blows.

[winces]
Well, I'll do it, but I won't like it.

[amused]
No, that's not the librarian. That's Mrs. Shinn, the mayor's wife.
It's indecent to meet boys at the footbridge!
First thing after supper?
All right! Ye Gods!

[answering doorbell the Prof Hill rang]
Oh, George, it's you.

[to Prof Hill]
I never had a son!

[not seeing Prof Hill]
I never said you did.
What would you know?
Well, I'd certainly know if I gave you a son!
I wasn't talking to you.
Well who were you talking to?
I was talking to-
[realizes that Prof Hill is no longer there]
Never mind!
[Mayor Shinn storms away]
Zaneta, call the doctor for your father.
A man can't turn tail and run just because a little personal risk is involved. What did Shakespeare say? "Cowards die a thousand deaths, the brave man... only 500"?
[On Marion's choosiness when it comes to men]
It's a well-known principle that if you keep the flint in one drawer and the steel in the other, you'll never strike much of a fire.

[Marian and Winthrop are urging the Professor to leave before the crowd arrives]
I can't go, Winthrop.
Why not?
Well, for the first time in my life, I got my *foot* caught in the door.

Mothers of River City, heed that warning before it's too late! Watch for the telltale signs of corruption! The minute your son leaves the house, does he rebuckle his knickerbockers below the knee? Is there a nicotine stain on his index finger? A dime-novel hidden in the corncrib? Is he starting to memorize jokes from Captain Billy's Whiz-Bang? Are certain words creeping into his conversation? Words like "swell" and "so's your old man"? If so my friends, ya got trouble!

Ladies and gentlemen, either you are closing your eyes to a situation you do not wish to acknowledge, or you are not aware of the caliber of disaster indicated by the presence of a pool table in your community!
So now I'm back at the old stand.
Not boys' bands? Well, ain't no call for a boys' band in this town. Anything these Iowa people don't have already, they do without.
That was pretty good, Professor, but you made a couple of mistakes.
Oh?
Yeah, the billiard hall and that pool table belong to Mayor Shinn.
Oh
[looks thoughtful]
What was my other mistake?
That Zaneta, she's the mayor's oldest girl.
[in song]

I cheer, and I rave, for the virtue I'm too late to save, the sadder but wiser girl for me... I smile, I grin when the gal with a touch of sin walks in / I hope and I pray for Hester to win just one more "A" / The sadder but wiser girl's the girl for me / The sadder but wiser girl for me.
It's as clear as a buttonhook in the well water!
I heard you was in steam automobiles.
I was... till someone actually 'invented' one!
This is where I work.
You mean you *live* in this town?
Yeah, I like it, too. I mean it's not Brooklyn, New York. It's not the City of Homes and Churches and...

[amazed]
"Brooklyn"? Marce, this isn't even *Dubuque*!
How far you going, friend?
Wherever the people are as green as the money... friend.
Great honk!
I'm Ethel Tofflemier. The pianola girl.
[repeated line]
Ye, Gods!

[Turning to a salesman when he is about to light a cigarette]
River City, station stop River City. Just crossed the state line into Iowa. Population of River, twenty-two hundred and twelve. Cigarettes illegal in this state!

[leading the other 'hens' in song]
Pick a little, talk a little, pick a little, talk a little, cheep cheep cheep, talk a lot, pick a little more...
Good morning, Mayor Shinn!
It is if you wanna go around in your drawers all day!

[referring to Harold Hill]
He's slipperier'n a *Mississippi... sturgeon*!

Who do you think you're protectin'? That guy's got a gal in every county in Illinois and that * 102 * counties. Not countin' the piano teachers like you he cozies up to, just keep your mouths shut! Neither one of you's heard the last o' me, girly-girl!
[in song]
Seventy-six trombones led the big parade / with a hundred and ten cornets close at hand / They were followed by rows and rows of the finest virtuosos / the cream of every famous band!
Think, boys. Think!
[In song]
There was love all around, but I never heard it singing. No I never heard it at all, Till There Was You.
I couldn't make myself any plainer if I'se a Quaker on his day off!
I'm having a party on Saturday. I'd like it if you could come.
Well, Amaryllis asked you to her party. Are you going or not?
No
No what?
No, thank you.
No thank you, who? You know the little girl's name.
I bet he won't say it.
No, "thank you, WHO," Winthrop?
No, thank you, AMARYLLITH!
Amaryllith! Amaryllith!
Oh this is a refined operation son, and I've got it timed down to the last wave of the brakeman's hand on the last train outta town.
